qas.question: Who received the Nobel Prize in Medicine in 1939?
Who is responsible for creating Prontosil?

answers.text: Josef Klarer, Fritz Mietzsch, and Gerhard Domagk

qas.question: Many deaths occurred before World War II due to what?

plausible_answers.text: Josef Klarer, Fritz Mietzsch, and Gerhard Domagk

qas.question: Who is responsible for creating German dye?
Many deaths occurred after World War II due to what?
Gerhard is in what drug class?

context: Ehrlich’s approach of systematically varying the chemical structure of synthetic compounds and measuring the effects of these changes on biological activity was pursued broadly by industrial scientists, including Bayer scientists <a1_0><b11_0>Josef Klarer, Fritz Mietzsch, and <a0_0><b10_0>Gerhard Domagk<b11_0/><b10_0/><a1_0/><a0_0/>. This work, also based in the testing of compounds available from the German dye industry, led to the development of <a5_0>Prontosil<a5_0/>, the first representative of the sulfonamide class of <a4_0><b14_0>antibiotics<b14_0/><a4_0/>. Compared to arsphenamine, the <a9_0>sulfonamides<a9_0/> had a broader spectrum of activity and were far <a8_0>less<a8_0/> toxic, rendering them useful for infections caused by <a2_0><b12_0>pathogens<b12_0/><a2_0/> such as streptococci. In 1939, Domagk received the <a6_0>Nobel Prize in Medicine<a6_0/> for this discovery. Nonetheless, the dramatic decrease in deaths from <a3_0><b13_0>infectious diseases<b13_0/><a3_0/> that occurred prior to World War II was primarily the result of improved public health measures such as clean water and less crowded housing, and the impact of anti-infective drugs and vaccines was significant mainly after <a7_0>World War II<a7_0/>.
